name: 施欣文
schedule: Each week students will continue their drafts for the senior project, holding regular meetings with their advisor and reading both suggested books and articles and books and articles discovered through their own research. Students' final senior project drafts (20 pages, excluding the Works Cited page, in 12-point Times New Roman font, will be due in mid-December. Students will defend their senior projects in early January during an oral presentation in front of a panel of professors and their peers.
scorePolicy: Each professor has his or her own standards for grading the senior project, generally based on the student's effort; ability to find, read, and make use of strong sources; critical thinking; originality; responsibility in setting and meeting writing goals (on time); ability to write clear and effective prose; and ethical and accurate citation practices. Students must meet the twenty-page requirement and his or her advisor's other expectations (for example, some advisors require peer reviews, group meetings, and certain communication standards from their students).
materials:
Students should select the best critical editions of the texts they need for their senior project, purchasing key texts if necessary (and affordable). 

Students should make use of the best library databases at Taipei Tech (including MLA International Bibliography, JSTOR, Project MUSE, Academic Search Complete, ERIC, the Oxford English Dictionary [for word history], and others that are relevant). Students will also probably wish to consult NTU's specialized databases for resources for their project.  Students should consult the Taipei Tech Library catalog for book and e-book sources, as well as Metacat for sources available at other libraries (including nearby NTU). Students should use Google Scholar to find more recent sources that have cited sources they rely on for their work. 

Students should make sure the sources they use are reputable, peer-reviewed scholarly work. 

Students may also rely on field research or experiments as needed, particularly for linguistics projects.
